item.title: Agriculture in Kenya as a Portfolio Problem
item.description: Motivation In 08. A New Walking Shoe: Modern Portfolio Theory , Malkiel introduced me to Modern Portfolio Theory, a technique for reducing portfolio risk, despite risky investments. It made me wonder how similar principles are applied in agriculture. This page is the result of that investigation. ~16% of Kenya’s land is sufficiently fertile and has good rainfall. In 2006, ~75% of working Kenyans are farmers (compared to 80% in 1980). (en.

item.title: Investing in Capital Markets
item.description: The Stock Market To trade in the NSE, open a CDS account with a CDA (some commercial banks, stockbrokers, investment banks). In 2006, an Automatic Trading System was introduced so that orders are matched automatically and executed by stockbrokers on a first-come first-served basis. Govt bonds have also been added to the ATS. Securities lending, short-selling and same day turnaround trades are not yet permitted. (kestrelcapital.com) I guess that’s why quant funds are not a thing in Kenya.

item.title: Investment Vehicles in Kenya
item.description: Investing through Groups (Chamas) www.kaig.org has developed a Chama Handbook to boost accountability and profitability. But chamas have a higher chance of being guided by friendships than profitability. For instance, how do I go about picking a chama? It’s most likely a referral from a friend who’s already in a chama. Kenya USA Diaspora Sacco Mavuno Term Deposit pays 8% interest for >1m KES and <2m KES deposited for a year.

item.title: It's All About Real Estate
item.description: It’s All About Real Estate I admit that I’m biased towards the conclusion that the Kenyan real estate market is in a bubble. My ‘evidence’ is the notion that people are buying land, holding onto it as it appreciates, then selling it off. Reminds me of Malkiel’s discussion on how the crowd can get uber-speculative, abandoning reality itself Questions to Dig Into Who is in real estate? Who are the main players?

item.title: Starting a Business in Kenya
item.description: http://www.invest.go.ke/ has 3 components: A database on Vision 2030 projects and mega-investment opportunities An investor guide: labor matters, taxes, investor rights, etc. eRegulations platform: setting up and running businesses. Many steps need to be completed in Kenya. Appoint an agent if need be. Types of business vehicles: sole proprietorship, company, foreign company with local branch, LLP, partnership

item.title: The Curious Case of African ETFs
item.description: etfdb.com has ETFs tracking regions. Surprised that Kenya isn’t on it . And they’re all losing money - best (over 5 years) is SA at -14.59%, Nigeria is at -64% . Why all the PR on Africa being the next big investment scene? Of course, Kenya’s the premier investment destination (invest.go.ke) Am I reading this right?? SOXL (semiconductors) ETF has >700% return over 5 years etfdb.
